Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: MSI--Mid-Latitude SuperDARN Radar Infrastructure for the Study of Ionospheric Electrodynamics and Atmospheric Processes on Global Scales
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this Mid-Size Infrastructure (MSI) project is to build a mid-latitude extension of the SuperDARN High Frequency (HF) radar network. Radars in the international SuperDARN network measure important properties of Earth's ionosphere, including electric fields, plasma structures, and acoustic gravity waves. Progress in the study of Earth's near-space environment increasingly relies on the availability of these critical measurements on global scales. The interest in SuperDARN data products has spurred the recent development of a pair of polar cap radars by Canadian colleagues, extending SuperDARN capabilities to the highest latitudes. This MSI project, which is a collaborative effort involving four institutions, will result in eight new radars distributed over four sites situated along an arc extending from the Azores through the central United States to the Aleutian Island chain. The new radars will provide unprecedented views of the dynamics of the subauroral ionosphere and inner magnetosphere. The feasibility of such measurements at middle latitudes has been demonstrated with the deployments of single, isolated SuperDARN radars in the eastern United States (Wallops Island, Blackstone) and in Japan (Hokkaido). The existing radars will be operationally folded into the MSI chain. The realization of this large-scale and long-term observational capability will furnish the space physics community with new infrastructure and a valuable tool for engaging students in cutting-edge research. SuperDARN data collected from high latitudes are used by space scientists all over the world. The existing radar network was developed incrementally over 15 years with the steady addition of international partners. This project will initiate the acquisition of comparable infrastructure at mid-latitudes thereby taking advantage of recent developments at polar latitudes and the existing high-latitude SuperDARN network to provide expanded coverage of effects in the magnetosphere, ionosphere, and neutral atmosphere. The protocols and distribution methods currently used for SuperDARN data and data products will be utilized to ensure the same ease of access to data. As occurred with high latitude SuperDARN, international partners are simultaneously seeking funds to build complementary radars in Europe and Asia. The participants in this project are all associated with institutions of higher learning and view the infrastructure as both a teaching and research investment. Data from the high-latitude SuperDARN radars have contributed to numerous advanced degrees and the mid-latitude extension will furnish many more opportunities. Students at the collaborating institutions will be heavily engaged in the work of this project both at their home institutions and at the individual radar sites. Measurements provided by the infrastructure will enable transformational science and support research across a broad range of topics in the physics of the magnetosphere, ionosphere, and upper atmosphere. At the same time, this effort will: (1) provide the research community with extensive mid-latitude ionospheric and atmospheric datasets; (2) provide large-scale context for ongoing and future spacecraft and rocket missions; (3) generate new research possibilities in space science for students; (4) provide opportunities for students at U.S. universities to gain hands-on experience with radar technology and in the management of a major scientific collaboration. All data and data products will be made freely available through the SuperDARN website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth’s ionosphere begins near 80 km altitude and extends upwards many hundreds of kilometers to regions where the atmosphere thins out and Earth’s magnetic field stands off the solar wind.  At auroral latitudes the weakly ionized plasma of the ionosphere is subjected to particle precipitation and strong electric fields that map down from the outer regions. As a result the high-latitude ionosphere is highly variable and exhibits a range of disturbance effects that disrupt technological systems and are collectively known as space weather. Since the 1990s a network of HF radars organized as an international collaboration has operated to map the large-scale circulation of ionospheric plasma over the polar regions. This circulation expresses very directly the coupling of energy from the solar wind into Earth’s near space environment and the radar measurements have found wide application in research conducted in the U.S. and abroad. The international collaboration is known as the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN) and its heritage can be traced back to pioneering efforts by U.S. scientists in the 1980s. The first chains of SuperDARN radars were constructed at high latitudes (e.g., Canada, Scandinavia, Antarctica) in order to have the zone of auroral activity within view for relatively undisturbed conditions.

In the mid-2000s SuperDARN radars were built at two sites in Virginia to test the capabilities of the technique at mid-latitudes, that is, at latitudes below those of the quiet-time auroral zone. They observed a range of dramatic effects including the expansion of the auroral zone to mid-latitudes during geomagnetic storms, conditions that produce aurora over the lower 48 U.S. states and lead to heightened risk of space weather disruption. This award to Virginia Tech resulted from a proposal to the NSF Mid-Sized Infrastructure (MSI) program to develop a mid-latitude chain of SuperDARN radars extending across the United States into eastern Asia. Awards were made to three other collaborating institutions: Dartmouth College, University of Alaska Fairbanks, and the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory. The groups pooled their resources and expertise and built a total of six radars distributed over three sites – Hays (Kansas), Christmas Valley (Oregon), and Adak (Alaska). Combined with the existing radars in Virginia these new radars make up a mid-latitude chain that greatly expands coverage of space weather phenomena in the ionosphere, especially during times of major disturbance when the auroral zone expands equatorward. Figure 1 shows how the fields of view of the new radars connect with each other and how their coverage is extended into eastern Asia by two complementary Japanese radars now operating in Hokkaido. The data from the radars are contributing to the SuperDARN data stream and access to the data and data products for the research community has been enhanced with the deployment of a range of analysis tools to the Virginia Tech SuperDARN website (vt.superdarn.org). 

This award specifically funded the contribution of Virginia Tech, the lead-PI institution, to the project. The Virginia Tech group purchased the antenna poles and related hardware for all the radar builds. It assumed the responsibility for construction and operation of the first pair of radars. Figure 2 shows an aerial photo of the site near Hays, Kansas, located on land contributed by a contractual partner on the build, Fort Hays State University. The Virginia Tech group contributed staff to the builds in Oregon and Alaska, provided managerial oversight to the project, and lead in developing new methods of data distribution and specialized web tools to facilitate user access to the data product. The other collaborating groups made comparable contributions in purchases of equipment and staff effort, as detailed in their report...
